item.title: Ukraine's Stolen Children Fight to Get Home: 'This Is My Country'
item.description: Kids forcibly removed from occupied territory by Russia are racing against time with the help of charities and governments—and their own wits—to get back to their home country.

item.title: Looming TikTok Ban Gives Young Voters Another Beef With Biden
item.description: Legislation restricting the app is popular, but many users feel betrayed.

item.title: Apple Retail Employees at Maryland Store Vote to Authorize Strike
item.description: The iPhone-maker is continuing to negotiate with the union representing about 100 workers at a store near Baltimore.

item.title: Stubbornly High Rents Prevent Fed From Finishing Inflation Fight
item.description: For more than a year, the central bank has expected slowing rent increases to show up in official housing measures. It’s still waiting.

item.title: Marriage Takes Work---Especially When Only One Spouse Retires
item.description: Relationships get complicated when one spouse retires and the other keeps working.

item.title: More »
item.description: A broken marriage, a big inheritance and the murder of an art kingmaker

item.title: More »
item.description: People from Silicon Valley to Wall Street are obsessed with this podcast

item.title: Rare Solar Storm Brings Light Shows to Night Sky
item.description: A powerful geomagnetic storm, caused by solar activity, creates northern lights in the skies of the U.S. and England and some irregularities to electrical grids.

item.title: He Put More Than $60 Million Into a Senate Race He Might Not Win
item.description: In Maryland, deep-pocketed David Trone faces Angela Alsobrooks in the Democratic primary on Tuesday.

item.title: Rafah Once Was a Refuge From the War. Now Gazans Don't Know Where to Go.
item.description: “Bombing is everywhere.” Israeli strikes and armed clashes in the Southern Gaza city have sparked another Palestinian mass migration.

item.title: Biden Is Losing Latino Voters to Trump. In Arizona, This Democrat Is Winning Them Over.
item.description: Ruben Gallego’s Senate contest against Republican Kari Lake will be a marquee race this fall in a top battleground state.

item.title: The All-Staff Goodbye Email
item.description: Why do departing staffers forward their farewells to coworkers they don’t even know? A Wall Street Journal comic about the modern workplace.

item.title: The Week in Photos, From the Met Gala to the Kentucky Derby
item.description: Eurovision Song Contest, storms in the U.S., Victory Day and more images from around the world, selected by Wall Street Journal photo editors.

item.title: More »
item.description: This common running shoe myth might be costing you money

item.title: California Beaches Are a New Gateway for Illegal Immigration
item.description: Migrants who want to avoid the Mexican border are arriving on boats, then rushing into waiting vehicles.

item.title: Should We Use AI to Re-Create Our Loved Ones After They Die?
item.description: New technology can let us see and hear representations of those we’ve lost. Will that bring comfort? Or will it distort the grieving process?

item.title: If Taylor Swift Can Dazzle Through the Tears, So Can You
item.description: Fans power through challenges to excel in life and work, led by star’s hit “I Can Do It With a Broken Heart.”

item.title: Why TV's Annual Upfront Sales Might Seem Like Groundhog Day
item.description: Media companies next week will pitch their TV networks and streaming platforms to advertisers with star-studded upfront sales presentations at glitzy venues around New York City. But ad buyers in the audience will also be keeping an eye on the Federal Reserve.

item.title: AI Startups Are Making Their Home in New York. Can They Turn It Into an AIPowerhouse?
item.description: A new class of startups is setting up shop in New York City instead of Silicon Valley, hoping to tap its concentration of businesses ready to buy AI applications.

item.title: The 'Save the Oceans' Tax Break: Recycling Oyster Shells
item.description: People love to eat oysters. The shells often end up in landfills. These restaurants want to repurpose them—and save some money.
